Comment: I want you to first understand that I‚Äôm not trying to attack you here. These are the first things that come to most people‚Äôs mind when they weigh both sides of this issue. I believe thinking critically about this issue leads to a deeper understanding of its importance, so I‚Äôm not unhappy to be having this discussion. What I merely hope to do is show that the mission of setting the marriage age in line with the age of majority around the world is a good and just cause that should be supported by everyone and that there is truly and absolutely no reason to allow exceptions.  The first important thing to understand is how there is no foolproof way to weed out the cases where the marriage is consensual and the cases where the marriage is forced.   Parental consent does not help because parents almost always play a crucial role in facilitating a forced marriage and that consent can very often be coercion.  Some states have a judicial approval system in place. These vary wildly from judges who never even see the minor and just need to sign off on the fact that the parent consents to a full scale hearing where the minor is represented by a guardian ad litem and is required to have an in-camera interview with the judge where they swear on record that the marriage is consensual. The problem is, no matter how robust the judicial approval system, there is always the possibility that the minor will lie. When a minor is forced to marry, they are also forced to lie to the judge about it.   Lastly, minors don‚Äôt have the same rights as an adult facing a forced marriage. In most states they can‚Äôt leave home, enter a domestic violence shelter, hire a lawyer or independently bring a legal action like filing a protective order against parents forcing them to marry. Even if the minor is emancipated, their rights are only limited and may not cover everything listed above, including access to a DV shelter.  These rights also make it very difficult for an already married minor to leave a consensual marriage that becomes abusive. In some states, minors can‚Äôt even file for divorce.  Also, your statement that a blanket ban on child marriage would dissolve marriages that already occurred is false. In each of the 14 states that have ended child marriage, the legislation is prospective and only applies to marriages that have yet to occur. They don‚Äôt dissolve the marriages of two people in their 80s who married at 17 and 18 decades ago. No advocates working in this space would draft or support legislation that dissolves existing marriages. All this legislation does is eliminate the existing loopholes that allow a minor to be issued a marriage license.  With that, let‚Äôs turn to your examples of when a marriage could be beneficial to a minor.  Health insurance - First of all, for a number of reasons, a pregnant teen needs more protection from an underage marriage than a teen who isn‚Äôt pregnant. One of the most common reasons that a minor (in the US at least) is forced to marry is because of a pregnancy. If for some reason, that teen cannot get health insurance from her parents, there are systems in place like Medicaid that she can get coverage through. Post delivery, states make it rather easy to establish paternity outside of wedlock. Sometimes it just a form the father needs to fill out. Then all of his insurance and other benefits extend to his child.  Asylum - If a minor was already legally married abroad, any marriage they entered into upon arriving in the US would be void due to polygamy laws. Our immigration system is pretty broken, but asylees do not need to get married to retain their asylee status. Green card marriages create a pathway towards permanent residency, but a minor would never be expected to enter into a marriage to retain their asylee status. If they want to enter into a green card marriage when they turn 18, they can certainly do that.  Abusive parents - As I mentioned above, parents almost always play a crucial role in facilitating a forced marriage. Nearly every state requires parental consent for a minor to marry. I find it hard to believe there would be parents who are routinely abusing their child, but would also consent to their marriage so the minor can escape their abuse. Further, studies show that minors who marry are more likely to experience domestic violence and, as I mentioned above, that minor faces really difficult legal and practical barriers if they want to leave that marriage. This really becomes an out of the frying pan and into the fire kind of situation. A minor‚Äôs temporary hardship should not be used to set them up for a lifetime of hardships. Besides the higher rates of domestic violence, minors who marry are more likely to experience a myriad of physical and mental disorders, they‚Äôre more likely to drop out of school, and they‚Äôre more likely to experience economic hardship and instability. The solution to a minor in an abusive household is Child Protective Services, not marrying her off.  I hope this all makes sense.
